results.definition: extend in scope or range or area
examples: The law was extended to all citizens
widen the range of applications
broaden your horizon
Extend your backyard

results.definition: stretch out over a distance, space, time, or scope; run or extend between two points or beyond a certain point
examples: Service runs all the way to Cranbury
His knowledge doesn't go very far
My memory extends back to my fourth year of life
The facts extend beyond a consideration of her personal assets

results.definition: span an interval of distance, space or time
examples: The war extended over five years
The period covered the turn of the century
My land extends over the hills on the horizon
This farm covers some 200 acres
The Archipelago continues for another 500 miles

results.definition: make available; provide
examples: extend a loan
The bank offers a good deal on new mortgages

results.definition: thrust or extend out
examples: He held out his hand
point a finger
extend a hand
the bee exserted its sting

results.definition: reach outward in space
examples: The awning extends several feet over the sidewalk

results.definition: offer verbally
examples: extend my greetings
He offered his sympathy

results.definition: extend one's limbs or muscles, or the entire body
examples: Stretch your legs!
Extend your right arm above your head

results.definition: expand the influence of
examples: The King extended his rule to the Eastern part of the continent

results.definition: lengthen in time; cause to be or last longer
examples: We prolonged our stay
She extended her visit by another day
The meeting was drawn out until midnight

results.definition: extend or stretch out to a greater or the full length
examples: Unfold the newspaper
stretch out that piece of cloth
extend the TV antenna

results.definition: cause to move at full gallop
examples: Did you gallop the horse just now?

results.definition: open or straighten out; unbend
examples: Can we extend the legs of this dining table?

results.definition: use to the utmost; exert vigorously or to full capacity
examples: He really extended himself when he climbed Kilimanjaro
Don't strain your mind too much

results.definition: prolong the time allowed for payment of
examples: extend the loan

results.definition: continue or extend
examples: The civil war carried into the neighboring province
The disease extended into the remote mountain provinces

results.definition: increase in quantity or bulk by adding a cheaper substance
examples: stretch the soup by adding some more cream
extend the casserole with a little rice

results.definition: relatively long in duration; tediously protracted
examples: a drawn-out argument
an extended discussion
a lengthy visit from her mother-in-law
a prolonged and bitter struggle
protracted negotiations

results.definition: fully extended or stretched forth
examples: an extended telescope
his extended legs reached almost across the small room
refused to accept the extended hand

results.definition: drawn out or made longer spatially
examples: Picasso's elongated Don Quixote
lengthened skirts are fashionable this year
the extended airport runways can accommodate larger planes
a prolonged black line across the page

results.definition: beyond the literal or primary sense
examples: `hot off the press' shows an extended sense of `hot'

results.definition: large in spatial extent or range or scope or quantity
examples: an extensive Roman settlement in northwest England
extended farm lands
surgeons with extended experience
they suffered extensive damage
